title: 109_hr5911
content:
The Act titled "Eradication of Slavery in Sudan Act of 2006" establishes its short title. It also outlines the establishment and composition of the Act. The United States Commission to Monitor Slavery and its Eradication in Sudan, known as the "Commission," is established with six members who are US citizens not employed by the Federal Government. Members are appointed by the President and the President pro tempore of the Senate. The Commission to Monitor Slavery and its Eradication in Sudan has six members appointed by the President and Senate leaders from both political parties. Members are selected based on their expertise in abduction and enslavement issues. The Commission to Monitor Slavery and its Eradication in Sudan consists of six members appointed based on expertise in abduction and enslavement issues. Each member must obtain security clearance. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve a three-year term with eligibility for reappointment. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 60 days of all appointments. The Commission shall hold its initial meeting and elect a Chair. Subsequent meetings will be called by the Chair or three voting members. The Chair must hire an Executive Director within 60 days of the initial meeting. The Executive Director hired under subsection (e) shall prepare a workplan, devise a budget, hire staff, develop relationships with organizations, and work with the General Services Administration. Three voting members constitute a quorum, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The President shall provide administrative support for the Commission at no cost through the General Services Administration. Members of the Commission will receive travel expenses while performing services for the Commission. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission's primary responsibilities include reporting on progress in identifying and freeing slaves in Sudan, ensuring their safe passage and family reunification, documenting cases of slavery, providing education and support for former slaves, and ensuring justice for those responsible for slavery. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as necessary. It will evaluate US Government policies in response to Sudan's failure to eradicate slavery and recommend actions such as diplomatic inquiries, protests, sanctions, and withdrawal of assistance funds. The Commission may recommend policy options to the Secretary of State regarding the eradication of slavery in Sudan, including diplomatic commendation, public commendation, cultural exchanges, termination of Presidential actions, and increase in assistance funds. SEC. 4. REPORT OF THE COMMISSION.

The Commission must submit an annual report to the Secretary of State by October 1st detailing its efforts and recommendations for US policy options based on its evaluations. The report may be classified, and members can include individual or dissenting views.

SEC. 5. APPLICABILITY OF OTHER LAWS.

The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission.

SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$1,000,000 for fiscal year 2007 and $1,500,000 for fiscal year 2008 are authorized to be appropriated to the Commission. The funds will remain available until expended but not later than the termination of the Commission.

SEC. 7. TERMINATION.

The Commission will terminate six years after the initial appointment of all members.
